data.title: Michael Cera Breaks Down His Most Iconic Characters
data.meta_description:
Michael Cera breaks down his most iconic roles in film and television, including 'Superbad,' 'Scott Pilgrim vs. the World,' 'Arrested Development,' 'Barbie,' 'Juno,' 'Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist,' 'This Is The End,' 'Twin Peaks' and his newest film 'The Adults.'
Variance Films will release THE ADULTS in select theaters across the US on August 18. Watch this episode for a sneak peek at an exclusive clip.
SAG-AFTRA members are currently on strike; as part of the strike, union actors are not promoting their film and TV projects. This interview was conducted prior to the strike.
Director: Robby Miller
Director of Photography: Zach Eisen
Editor: Graham Mooney
Creative Producer: Arielle Neblett
Line Producer: Jen Santos
Associate Producer: Chris Sechler
Production Manager: James Pipitone
Production Coordinator: Jamal Colvin
Talent Booker: Meredith Judkins
Camera Operator: Kyle LeClaire
Audio Engineer: Sean Paulsen
Production Assistant: Shenelle Jones
Post Production Supervisor: Rachael Knight
Post Production Coordinator: Ian Bryant
Supervising Editor: Rob Lombardi
Assistant Editor: Courtney Karwal
data.text:
My manager got a call

checking on my availability for it

and he called me and he said,

I got a call about this movie. It's the Barbie movie.

Greta Gerwig's directing it.

Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling are starring in it

and it's filming in London for four months or something.

So I told them

you probably wouldn't want to do it

'cause you probably don't want to go to London.

[Michael laughs] And I was like, What?!

What do you mean?

Call them back.

[energetic music]

Superbad.

[Teacher] So i is an imaginary number.

It doesn't really exist.

If i equals...

It was sort of this long audition process.

I felt I had to keep proving myself.

I mean, nobody...

There were kind of,

it was kind of,

I guess, felt like it was going in a good direction,

that they kept bringing me back.

But, actually, the way I found out I got the part

was from Jonah.

One day, I got a voicemail from Jonah, saying,

Hey, we're gonna do this movie together,

so we have to hang out.

Judd says we have to hang out.

And that was really how I found out I got the movie

and that Jonah was gonna be in it.

And I was so excited that it was gonna be him

because, you know,

he hadn't sort of occurred to me

as someone who could play that part,

but when I found out it was gonna be him,

I really felt like it was gonna be a great movie

because I had done a couple table reads with Jonah,

actually, for other projects,

and Jonah was just always astoundingly great at them.

And he would be one of those guys sometimes

that they would throw a couple parts at,

you know, like, You do a handful of parts.

Every single thing that they threw at him,

he would make, you know,

so interesting,

and so much more interesting than it was.

It would just be a very flat thing

and he would bring so much character to it.

So I knew how great he was

and was very excited to get to do that movie with him.

I should buy Becca alcohol?

Yeah, and then we pimp.

That way, you know she'll be drunk.

You know when you hear a girl saying, like,

Aw, I was so shit-faced last night.

I shouldn't have fucked that guy.?

We could be that mistake!

Jonah and I are friends to this day

and I think we just are naturally friends.

I mean, it's up to you, Fogell.

This guy's either gonna think,

Here's another kid with a fake ID,

or, Here's McLovin,

the 25-year-old Hawaiian organ donor.

Okay? So what's it gonna be?

I am McLovin.

Yah.

No, you're not. No one's McLovin.

McLovin's never existed

'cause that's a made up dumb fuckin' fairytale name,

you fuck!

When we made the movie,

I think it cost like $20-million to make

and so it didn't feel like a small movie to me.

I mean, it already felt

like the biggest thing that had ever happened to me,

just getting the job

and getting to make it,

so it kind of felt to me

like a bit of a given

that it would be a big movie

or else it would've been a big failure.

It was so popular

and I was so recognizable suddenly,

and so were all of us,

and it's a strange adjustment to make,

you know,

but it was kind of helpful to do it all together

and we sort of just had our heads down

and were going on this giant press tour

and it all just felt like this big,

you know, tumble dry cycle of craziness.

It was helpful to go through it together

and figure it out as we went.

[energetic music]

Scott Pilgrim vs. the World.

[acoustic guitar music]

♪ Ramona ♪

♪ Ramona ♪

♪ On my mind ♪

♪ Ramona ♪

Can't wait to hear it when it's finished.

I was such a fan of Edgar's

from Spaced and Shaun of the Dead

and Hot Fuzz.

Well, Edgar actually had visited the set

of Arrested Development

and was friends with, I think,

with David and Jason and Will,

and I didn't get a chance to meet him when he came

and I was kind of disappointed.

But when I, just,

you know, when Edgar reached out,

when I was even just in contact with him,

I was really excited because I was a big fan.

I knew he was incredibly talented.

It was exciting to me.

It was sort of like too good to be true

because I also loved the graphic novels.

It just felt

fortunate to be the right age,

the right time.

Yeah. It just, it was a lucky thing.

What did I do?

[Matthew yelling]

What do I do?

[Matthew yelling]

Fight!

Fight! Fight!

[Matthew yelling]

[video game sounds]

[fist landing]

[video game sounds]

It was so much fun.

It was a long shoot, I think.

I mean, for me in particular,

because other people kind of came and went, you know?

But I was there for, I think, nine months or something,

which is an enormous amount of time

to work on something.

But it was so much fun all the time

because we just had the greatest vibe with everybody.

I think that basically trickled down from Edgar

and the energy that he was creating

and we all got to rehearse together

and spend a lot of time together

before we even started making the movie.

By the end of the movie,

I felt like, This is my world.

This is my group of friends.

It kind of feels like,

Oh, it's always gonna be this way.

And honestly,

I kind of was a little depressed

when we were done

because

it all,

you know, it all just goes away,

and you're like, Where did everybody go?

You know?

So you kind of get used to that as you get older

and as you're acting for a while.

But I was sad to lose it.

I could have kept making that forever,

even though it was exhausting.

[energetic music]

[Scott grunting]

[coins falling]

[energetic music]

[coins falling]

[video game sounds]

We were kind of doing endurance training

more than anything,

more than bodybuilding or something.

And fight training,

you know, choreography,

which is just so unnatural to me

and sometimes hurt.

There were a couple times where I got hurt.

Like I...

Just even blocking a kick,

trying to block over and over

and find the right point in space to put your hand.

And one time I just went too low

and received the full blow of this guy's kick,

one of the stuntmen

who was just kicking at a point in air,

and it's an insane feeling

you can't believe is happening in your hand.

Like you didn't know

that you had these muscles in your hand.

Now they're throbbing

for like a week.

Like a train hit me in the hand, you know?

Very weird.

[energetic music]

Arrested Development.

The thing is that the year before Arrested Development,

I had done a sitcom that never aired

called The Grubbs,

which was a Fox multi-cam sitcom

starring Randy Quaid and Carol Kane.

You know, it was sort of,

it just didn't,

it never aired.

We shot eight episodes of it.

It was maybe sort of formulaic,

like family,

dysfunctional family sitcom.

It was really funny.

It was written by really funny writers,

but it was sort of situational

and I was playing sort of a stock teenage part, maybe.

And then when I got the role in Arrested Development

and had this whole storyline

that was really insane

of being in love with my,

secretly in love with my first cousin...

I should go to my mom tonight

and be like, I met the cutest guy.

And then she'll see you and me totally making out.

Yeah. [George laughs]

But not really, right?

I just remember being really grateful as a kid

to have such a strange through-line storyline

in a show as a kid.

Because I feel like teenage roles in TV shows

are sort of stock

and you don't get too much to sink your teeth into

other than being precocious or being whatever.

So I was excited about that,

and saw a lot of humor in it and, you know,

I just thought it was always really so funnily handled

that Jason Bateman is just completely oblivious to it.

You stay on top of her, buddy.

Do not be afraid to ride her.

Hard.

[upbeat music]

I was just so excited

to be a part of such a great troupe of actors, too,

and be around these people all the time.

It was the greatest thing.

Do you know the last time

that I made love to my wife?

No.

I'll tell you when. No, don't.

See, nothing has ever been easy for us.

I mean, the only reason she went out with me

was to piss off her boyfriend.

The only reason she ever married me

was to piss off her mother.

And then, of course, we couldn't conceive.

So there was that famous ordeal.

What do you mean you couldn't conceive?

[phone ringing] Was Maeby adopted?

Is she not really related to me?

Is she just some girl I know?

I was really excited

when they started writing

sort of these side storylines

that involved myself and David Cross,

like having one-on-one scenes together,

because I loved David

and I worshiped David, actually,

before ever getting to meet him

or work with him.

'Cause I watched Mr. Show growing up.

Where I grew up,

every Friday night there was The Tom Green Show

and Mr. Show

slotted as an hour,

and me and my friend watched it,

like, religiously.

So when I heard David was potentially gonna be in the pilot,

I was incredibly excited.

And then they started writing scenes

with David and I,

when he becomes kind of my roommate.

We're sharing the bunk bed at some point

in one of the earlier seasons.

And those were always so much fun to film

and really hard for me to keep it together.

I have to wear it all the time.

You'd never understand.

Oh, please.

I'll never un...

I'll never understand?

That you can never be nude?

[robe hits floor]

I understand more than you'll

never know.

Yeah, it was completely intimidating.

They were completely encouraging

and supportive with me and Alia,

who's my cousin on the show,

who, you know, we were the two children on the show.

And it's like,

it just is intimidating

because they're all operating

on this insanely high level of intellect

and humor

and they're so fast

and they're so brilliant.

But even though it was intimidating,

I feel like we just benefited enormously

by getting to be around it and soak them up

and be part of it, and just,

you know, be part of the fun

that they were creating.

[energetic music]

Barbie.

It was a kind of very last-minute casting.

My manager got a call

checking on my availability for it.

And he called me and he said,

I got a call about this movie.

It's the Barbie movie.

Greta Gerwig's directing it

and it's filming in London

for, you know, four months or something.

So I told them you probably wouldn't want to do it

'cause you probably don't want to go to London.

[Michael laughs] I was like, What?!

What do you mean?

Call them back.

I mean, he didn't, like,

blow it or anything,

but he's like,

I managed their expectations

that you might not wanna do it.

And I was like, How can I not do it?

I need to do it.

So I somehow got Greta's email address,

I think through a common friend of ours,

and I emailed her.

I was like, Can I be,

[Michael laughs] Can I do that part?

And she was like, Let's get on a Zoom right now.

Here's a Zoom link.

I'll be on there for the next hour.

So she was just hanging out on the Zoom.

She's like, Just click that link whenever you're ready.

And then we talked about it

and it just all happened really fast from there.

Hi, Barbie.

Oh, hi, Allan.

[Narrator] There are no multiples of Allan.

He's just Allan.

Yeah, I'm,

I'm confused about that.

I mean, Allan is

a sad, you know,

figure.

He's just a person

that just doesn't really have any place in the world.

You know, Allan is actually based on a real doll

that enjoyed a very short production run, I think,

in, like, the year 1967.

It just wasn't selling.

I think the world just didn't need

for Ken to have a friend,

like, to supplement that wing of the collection.

It was like,

Barbie is good.

We can get a lot more Barbies in here

and friends of hers,

but we've got Ken

and we don't need to go deeper in that direction.

He can hold it down.

So Allan kind of,

you know,

fell by the wayside a little bit.

Honestly, there's been so much anticipation for the movie

ever since it was even,

we even started working on it.

I think it's just very infectious.

Maybe there's just something in the world right now

that people are ready for a Barbie movie.

They just,

it feels like just the right time

to have a Barbie movie.

I mean, even on the set,

everything was very infectious.

Everybody was wearing pink shoelaces and everything

and it was fun.

It was a good spirit right from the start.

[energetic music]

Juno.

What should we do?

Well, you know, I was just,

I was thinking I'd just nip it in the bud

before it gets worse

because they were talking about in health class

how pregnancy,

it can often lead to an infant.

Typically, yeah. Yeah.

That's what happens

when our moms and teachers get pregnant.

When I read the script the first time,

the thing that really grabs you

is the rhythm of it and the dialogue.

So you're cool with that then?

Yeah. Yeah. Wizard.

I mean, you know,

just, I guess,

do whatever you think you should do, you know?

It's very distinct in its voice, you know,

which I think Diablo Cody

has kind of made her,

you know, her hallmark in a way.

But I don't think anybody knew who she was when,

you know, that script came out of nowhere

and she just kind of wrote it

in a sandwich shop or something

and really carved this voice

out of nothing.

And I think actually she had a blog

that she was kind of a little famous for at the time.

But, yeah,

reading it for the first time,

that's just the thing that really knocks you out

is kind of the voice,

the voice of it.

I think I'm in love with you.

You mean as friends?

No.

I mean for real.

'Cause you're, like,

the coolest person I've ever met

and you don't even have to try,

you know?

I try really hard, actually.

I remember when the movie came out,

there was some,

I dunno,

promotional effort

that involved a bunch of guys

dressed in those track

suits

or the running, you know, outfit,

running around Hollywood in a cluster,

which was just,

you know, kind of funny and uncanny.

[energetic music]

Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist.

The thing that most drew me to it

was Pete Sollett,

who directed it.

He had made this incredible movie, Raising Victor Vargas.

It was stunningly great, that movie,

and I just wanted to do anything with him.

And then there was an amazing script

by Lorene Scarfaria, who,

yeah, had adapted it from the book

but did this great job

with the script.

So it just felt like it was gonna be good.

So that's it, Tris.

The breakup mix.

Ten songs from my broken...

That's not even real.

Can we go straight to laughing about this?

I have to pee.

Okay.

It was a month or longer

of night shoots,

which is,

you know, strange,

like,

strange biological experience,

sleeping with the sun up

and garbage trucks going by

and life outside your window,

and not sleeping very well.

But I was,

I think, 19 when I made that movie,

having the greatest time.

'Cause we would wrap at like 6:00 AM

and then we would go get soup at Veselka

or go, you know, hang out.

Honestly, it's probably the reason I live in New York today

because I really fell in love with the city

and the feeling of just wandering through it

and how alive it is

and how generous it is

as far as like a texture of life.

You just,

there's just always something of interest

happening all over the place

and sometimes you have to guard yourself against it.

It can be a lot.

But, like, I was just so drawn to it.

I got this.

Hey.

What's up, friend? How you doing?

Hey, I was just gonna go in the...

Hey. You walked right in here, didn't you, little bird?

I didn't mean to.

I'm sorry.

You're like a little canary in skinny jeans, huh?

Well, I was gonna go in there

just to look for my friend.

Oh. You got friends right here.

Me and Switzerland are here for you, baby.

Hey, thanks for coming by.

Let me ask you a question.

You ever hook up with a dog?

No.

What? Like an...

A dog, like a pet?

No.

Don't.

It's not worth it.

I like you so much.

I'm running away.

With that era,

there's like,

there was like a studio independent movie genre almost,

where they weren't really independent.

I mean, you know,

they were financed by studios

and they cost a lot of money,

but they sort of are labeled independent.

There's sort of a flavor,

like a lane that they found,

a genre

or something.

It seems like it's gone.

I mean, it seems like it's an era

where that model doesn't work anymore,

where movies being made at that level

or at that budget

that aren't, you know, superhero movies

or something that will be guaranteed to have an audience -

it just seems like

a sort of relic of that time.

I'm not sure if it'll come back,

but a $10-million movie or something,

you know, which used to be kind of normal

to get made,

and now,

I don't think they're being made anymore.

I think you either make, now,

a very small movie

that we can go make with this crew

or a giant movie.

So it's a little weird.

It's changed.

[energetic music]

This Is The End.

Hey. What's going on?

Hey, does this coke smell funny?

Oh, fuck, Michael!

Fuck!

[both yelling]

Some shit, motherfucker.

I've never fucking done cocaine, dude!

Well, you did the best shit possible for your first time.

'Cause that's good...

I'm not sure whose idea it was.

I guess it was Seth and Evan.

And, you know,

the thing that was,

was hugely beneficial for me

on that movie

was that I kind kind of came in late.

They had been shooting

and they'd been shooting that house party sequence

in particular

for, you know,

at least a week or so

before I got in.

I kind of had to come in late

'cause I was just finishing another job.

So when I got there,

they filled me in

on what everybody had been saying about me.

They had all been kind of describing me,

creating a character, really,

for me to step into.

And so they told me all that,

which was hilarious.

And then it was really just all there for me.

I just have to live up to what they're saying.

I have to be weird.

[Michael laughs]

So that was,

yeah.

[slap lands]

[slap lands] [Michael exclaims]

[Jason] That's not cool.

Don't touch my butt.

Michael, that's not cool, man.

Fuck off, Jason. We're playing a game, man.

Yeah, I mean she definitely hit me.

Yeah.

But I really,

I wanted that, you know.

I mean,

I think it's a lot funnier

and a lot more convincing.

I mean, a fake slap just doesn't look good.

So she hit me hard.

I mean, yeah,

she really sent me flying,

and it was great.

And now it's

on film forever,

this pain that I experienced.

[energetic music]

Twin Peaks.

Look who's here.

It's Wally.

We're so excited. He came in unannounced.

Good to see you again, Wally.

It's good to see you too, Sheriff Truman.

As you know,

your brother, Harry S. Truman, is my godfather.

Well, the full story, actually,

is that I met David Lynch,

I don't know,

a year or two earlier

because I had done a transcendental meditation course

where you go to the center,

they teach you how to do it,

they give you your mantra.

You go for like an hour over four days.

They just kind of make sure you've got a handle on it.

And the fourth day,

when I was leaving,

I was with a few friends of mine.

This woman just appeared,

and she was a young woman.

She said, My name is Pookie.

I work with David Lynch.

Would you guys like to meditate with David sometime?

And we were like, What?

What do you mean?

I mean, just unbelievable invitation

and, you know,

came out of outer space,

and we were like, That's insane.

I can't even say how profoundly important he is

to me.

I got there first.

I was the first one there.

I went up and met David alone

for like five minutes

and he was just so sweet.

I was like, What is this gonna be like?

I'm coming to his home. Is he gonna be annoyed?

Is he just kind of eyerollingly allotting this time to us

because someone convinced him to?

What is the situation?

But he was so welcoming,

so warm, so happy that we were there.

It was the four of us.

And we sat in his art studio at the back of his house

and meditated with him

and talked for a while.

A friend of mine who was there,

Jocelyn, was about to make her first film

and just had questions for him.

Like, Do you have any advice on directing?

And he gave great advice, very practical advice.

And that felt like it was gonna be it, you know?

And I was grateful to ever have met him.

And then a few years later,

got this invitation to come work with him

on this show,

for, you know, one day.

I think I was on that set for, like, two hours, tops.

And that was just the greatest experience.

I've crisscrossed this great land of ours

countless times.

I hold the map of it here,

in my heart,

next to the joyful memories

of the carefree days I spent

as a young boy.

That was just,

it was very specifically written.

It was a monologue.

They said, in the script, I think,

how I was dressed

and that I speak like Marlon Brando.

That was basically all

that was provided to me.

And so I prepared myself

and wanted to show up completely prepared,

but open to whatever he would want to adjust

or do or whatever.

But we hardly talked about it on set.

We did it a couple times.

He came over.

I think mostly he gave me notes

on some of the punctuations

in the monologue.

Like, Really hit that comma,

or whatever, you know,

small things like that.

Shaping the rhythm of it.

But just,

and then just very supportive.

And we did it just a few times and it was done.

And I really wish I could've spent much more time

working with him.

'Cause it was really,

it's really a joy.

[energetic music]

The Adults.

It is sort of a very mysterious character

as written

because

a lot is withheld.

The ambiguity, actually,

is sort of what the driving force of the story is,

actually -

the ambiguity that's happening between the characters.

This distance,

this gulf that's happening between them.

But that was,

I think, what was compelling to me

about reading the script, actually,

is everything that's living in the darkness

of the characters

and of their history

and that we don't know.

And the little pieces that we do see

are what we have to draw our conclusions from.

I have a hand.

Yeah?

Any good?

I think it's good.

Hmm.

Yeah, I have a hand.

I don't have the nuts or anything, but...

I'd played poker, you know,

before doing the movie.

I used to play in a home game,

a weekly home game

at my friend's house,

which, the game still stands,

but I don't live in Los Angeles anymore.

But they still play.

I used to love playing, just,

you know, just for the social aspect of it,

just to be there,

joke around,

and I would kind of just throw my money away

and lose.

I would lo...

And then there are some people

that were playing at a different level,

that seemed to have

an understanding of the game

and the fundamentals of it.

And so I knew

that they were playing on a different level than me,

but I was never really too curious

to go deeper with it

until I got cast in Molly's Game.

And then I thought, Maybe I should read a book,

a poker book,

and see what they know that I don't know.

There's something going on that I don't know.

But maybe I should just get interested in it.

And then once I did, I found it so bottomlessly fascinating.

I really love poker

to this day.

Love playing it.

I have kind of seasons

where I'm good at it

and then other times where I'm just terrible

and just can't get a handle on it.

But it's fun.
